The rigid rod is thus shorter when in motion than when at rest, and the more quickly it is moving, the shorter is the rod. From this we conclude that in the theory of relativity the velocity ccc plays the part of a limiting velocity, which can neither be reached nor exceeded by any real body.

Of course this feature of the velocity ccc as a limiting velocity also clearly follows from the equations of the Lorentz transformation, for these became meaningless if we choose values of vvv greater than ccc.

If we had based our considerations on the Galileian transformation we should not have obtained a contraction of the rod as a consequence of its motion.
